title: How losing their parents led two brothers to the Boston Marathon
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Connor and Collin Nally are participating in the 2026 Boston Marathon to raise funds for Dana-Farber Cancer Institute.
The brothers aim to raise $27,000 for cancer research in memory of their parents and fiancée's mother, all lost to cancer.
This race is Connor's first marathon, while Collin is running it for the second time, representing remembrance and renewal.

title: After stage 3 blood cancer, Lynnfield woman will return for 7th Boston Marathon
author: Autumn Sloboda
bullets: Allison Milford from Lynnfield will run her 7th Boston Marathon to raise funds for the Boston Athletic Association.
Milford, a cancer survivor, first participated in the marathon in 2011 after completing chemotherapy in 2009.
Her fundraising efforts support programs for at-risk children and promote health and fitness in the community.

title: DHS criticizes city councilor after chaotic ICE arrest in Roslindale
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: DHS criticized Boston City Councilor Enrique Pepén for alleging an ICE 'abduction' during a Roslindale operation on Feb. 5.
Councilor Pepén, supporting the Boston Trust Act, condemned ICE's action, while DHS accused him of smearing the agency.
ICE detained Jose Perez-Antonio, labeled a 'serial criminal', amid community efforts to mitigate ICE's impact under local sanctuary policies.

title: Nice weather kicks off the holiday weekend, but will the next storm system be a hit or miss?
author: David Epstein
bullets: Forecasters predict sunny weather with temperatures in the mid-30s for southern New England over the holiday weekend.
A coastal storm system is being monitored for Monday, with current predictions favoring minimal impact on New England.
Central/Western Mass and Rhode Island will see clear skies Saturday and Sunday, with clouds expected to move in Monday.

title: What K’Lavon Chaisson and Jaylinn Hawkins said about upcoming free agency
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: K'Lavon Chaisson and Jaylinn Hawkins will enter free agency next month, both expressing a desire to return to the Patriots.
Chaisson, who signed a one-year $3 million contract, had a breakout season with 7.5 sacks and 10 tackles for loss.
Hawkins recorded 71 tackles and four interceptions, emphasizing his strong bond with teammates and desire to stay in New England.

title: A Mass. middle school basketball coach collapsed during a game. The opposing coach sprang into action.
author: Samantha Genzer
bullets: Belmont Middle School coach Ian Haffer saved Waltham coach Ronnie Poirier's life after a heart attack during a basketball game.
Ian Haffer, a medical doctor, used a defibrillator and performed CPR on the court before paramedics arrived.
Coach Poirier remains in the ICU, communicating, with ongoing tests; Belmont supports students after witnessing the incident.

title: Another movie theater is shutting down in Massachusetts
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Showcase Cinema de Lux in Randolph will close on March 1, leaving seven locations in Massachusetts.
The Randolph theater, featuring IMAX and MX4D, was purchased by National Amusements for $4 million in 1997.
National Amusements Inc., now owned by Paramount Skydance, closed Randolph soon after Patriot Place cinema's closure.

title: Giveaway: Enter to win tickets to a screening of ‘Midwinter Break’
author: Boston.com Staff
bullets: Love Letters is giving away 10 pairs of tickets to 'Midwinter Break' screening on February 19 at AMC Boston Common.
Participants must submit a relationship question by February 17 for a chance to win tickets to the film screening.
Winners will be notified by February 18 and must be 18 years or older to enter the giveaway.

title: Boston meteorologists are ‘watching’ the track of a storm for Monday
author: John Waller
bullets: Meteorologists in Boston are closely monitoring a storm potentially impacting the area on Presidents' Day, with low confidence in its path.
Weather models show mixed signals on whether Monday's storm will bring snow or rain to New England.
The storm, currently tracking offshore, may change its path and affect New England by early next week.

title: Kendrick Perkins explained why the Celtics are ‘the most dangerous team in the NBA’
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Kendrick Perkins considers the Celtics the NBA's most dangerous team despite not being at full strength this season.
Jaylen Brown is highlighted by Perkins as a leading MVP candidate for his two-way play and scoring prowess.
Jayson Tatum's potential return is discussed, but Perkins believes the team remains formidable without him.
